# Introduction {.unnumbered}

*This chapter is under development. Check back soon for the full content.*

## What This Chapter Will Cover

- Definition and types of market failures in economic theory
- Externalities (positive and negative) and their Islamic treatment
- Public goods provision in Islamic economics and the role of waqf
- Information asymmetry and the Islamic prohibition of gharar
- The concept of gharar: uncertainty, ambiguity, and prohibited transactions
- Environmental externalities and Islamic stewardship
- Community welfare and the prevention of harm (maslaha)
- Islamic regulatory approaches versus conventional interventions

::: {.callout-tip title="Key Concept"}
Islamic economics addresses market failures through a combination of ethical constraints (prohibition of gharar, emphasis on transparency), institutional mechanisms (waqf for public goods, hisbah for market supervision), and community-based solutions rooted in the principle of preventing harm (maslaha) to society.
:::
